title: WebGIS: NYC Population
text:
In the navigation bar at the top right of the page, you will find:

An interactive ArcGIS Dashboard visualizing population in NYC by zip code.
Information regarding the data used in the visualization.
An example Open Letter Template that can be modified and used to contact your local representative(s).
Some information about this website—and me!

title: About
text:
The Assignment: To build our own multi-page website, bring together components from previous labs, and showcase geospatial data.
The Programming: This webpage was built with RStudio and Quarto, using HTML, JavaScript, and CSS languages. It also includes pages originally made in Observable (see: Open Letter) and with ArcGIS Online’s Dashboard (see: Map).

title: A Letter to the Mayor *
text:
A Letter to the Mayor *
*Sample exercise only.

Welcome! Please see the following selection and fill-in options to craft a personalized email to your elected official regarding NYC’s growing population and resulting housing shortage.

viewof AddresseeTitle = Inputs.select(["Mayor", "Congressperson", "Borough President", "Council Member", "Mr.", "Mrs.", "Ms."], 
      {value:"Mayor", label:"Addressee Title"})







viewof AddresseeName = Inputs.text({value: "Official's Name",label: "Addressee Name"})







viewof AuthorLetter = Inputs.text({value: "Your Name", label:"Your Name"})







Dear  ,
As I am sure you are aware, our beloved city is in the midst of a housing crisis.
In particular, the City’s housing crisis is marked by a severe shortage of affordable housing, driven by rising rents, stagnant wages, and a growing population. The City’s real estate market is dominated by luxury developments, while low- and middle-income residents struggle with high rent prices and limited availability of affordable units. Moreover, gentrification has displaced long-time residents in many neighborhoods, exacerbating inequality. Finally, the City’s zoning laws and slow pace of new construction have contributed to the lack of affordable housing options, creating significant barriers for those seeking stable, affordable homes.

Different areas of the city are differentially impacted by the growing population. This interactive map highlights NYC’s population and demographic breakdown by zip code as of 2021; zip codes with larger populations are visualized in increasingly darker shades. The data comes from City and census sources.
Additionally, you will find a simple breakdown of the top 5 most populous zip codes below:



Zip Code
Borough
Population




11368
Queens
113,741 people


11211
Brooklyn
107,788 people


11226
Brooklyn
101,747 people


11373
Queens
101,548 people


11220
Brooklyn
101,225 people



To address the needs of the growing population, we propose taking the following targeted action.

Build affordable housing on existing empty lots
Amend restrictive zoning laws
Convert empty office spaces to apartments

In particular I would like to emphasize the housing potential of formerly commercial spaces. Other regions of the country have had success turning former shopping malls into housing, and NYC’s surplus of office space could be similarly revitalized.


I look forward to your response and to working together!
Sincerely,

title: New York City Population and Demographic Overview, 2021
text:
In the navigation menu at the top of this website, you will find:

A link to an interactive ArcGIS Dashboard visualizing population in NYC by zip code.
Information regarding the data used in the visualization.
An example Open Letter Template that can be used to contact and inform your local representative.

title: Open Letter
text:
*Sample lab exercise only.



viewof AddresseeTitle = Inputs.select(["Mayor", "Congressperson", "Borough President", "Council Member", "Mr.", "Mrs.", "Ms."], 
      {value:"Mayor", label:"Addressee Title"})







viewof AddresseeName = Inputs.text({value: "Official's Name",label: "Addressee Name"})







viewof AuthorLetter = Inputs.text({value: "Your Name", label:"Your Name"})






Dear  ,
As I am sure you are aware, our beloved city is in the midst of a housing crisis.
In particular, the City’s housing crisis is marked by a severe shortage of affordable housing, driven by rising rents, stagnant wages, and a growing population. The City’s real estate market is dominated by luxury developments, while low- and middle-income residents struggle with high rent prices and limited availability of affordable units. Moreover, gentrification has displaced long-time residents in many neighborhoods, exacerbating inequality. Finally, the City’s zoning laws and slow pace of new construction have contributed to the lack of affordable housing options, creating significant barriers for those seeking stable, affordable homes.
Different areas of the city are differentially impacted by the growing population. This interactive map highlights NYC’s population and demographic breakdown by zip code as of 2021; zip codes with larger populations are visualized in increasingly darker shades. The data comes from City and census sources.
Additionally, you will find a simple breakdown of the top 5 most populous zip codes below:

```{ojs}
| Zip Code | Borough | Population |
| ------ | ------ | ------|
| 11368 | Queens | 113,741 people |
| 11211 | Brooklyn | 107,788 people |
| 11226 | Brooklyn | 101,747 people |
| 11373 | Queens | 101,548 people |
| 11220 | Brooklyn | 101,225 people |

```

To address the needs of the growing population, we propose taking the following targeted action.

Build affordable housing on existing empty lots
Amend restrictive zoning laws
Convert empty office spaces to apartments

In particular I would like to emphasize the housing potential of formerly commercial spaces. Other regions of the country have had success turning former shopping malls into housing, and NYC’s surplus of office space could be similarly revitalized.

title: Mapping Dashboard
text:
Darker shades show zip codes with larger populations.

















Click on zip codes of interest to see a popup with the full breakdown of demographic info.

title: Data
text:
The data presented in the visualizations and open letter on this website come from the Census Bureau. Population and demographic information are presented at the “Zip Code Tabulation Area” (ZCTA) level. More information about Census Bureau datasets and ZCTAs can be found at the links below.
Census Data
ZCTAs
